poem:
Title: "The Wealth of Interpretations"

In the web of currencies, whose chip shines brighter?
Is it the man at $150,000, crowned in cashlight,
or the 'typical' Aussie, potluck knight?
Does a pay envelope tell a rich man, dictate a writer?
Questions that trickle, twisted and tight,
asking us to name the price of our very delight.
Look again, friend, see wealth in each earthly sight.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "What makes someone rich? Find out how your income and wealth compares Questions like “is someone who earns over $150,000 a year rich?” or “how much does the average Australian earn?” seem like they should be easy to answer. But in practice both questions are tricky. For the latter you need to figure out whether you mean the “typical” Australian or the mean; whether or not to include only people who are employed, and so". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
